noun.description: A member of the British reforming and constitutional party that sought the supremacy of Parliament and was eventually succeeded in the 19th century by the Liberal Party.
An American colonist who supported the American Revolution.
Denoting a historian who interprets history as the continuing and inevitable victory of progress over reaction.

origin: Mid 17th century (in Whig (sense 3)): probably a shortening of Scots whiggamore, the nickname of 17th-century Scottish rebels, from whig to drive + mare.
